Name: smoke_toy_regression
Title: Smoke Test: Toy Regression (Torch Only, No External Data)
Short Hypothesis: A small MLP trained on synthetic data (y = sin(x) + noise) should quickly reduce validation MSE; this validates the end-to-end pipeline (code generation -> execution -> metrics parsing -> plots -> summaries).
Abstract: This is a deliberately simple, self-contained idea for connectivity testing. The experiment must not download datasets or use heavy extra dependencies. It should generate a synthetic regression dataset in-code with a fixed seed, train a tiny PyTorch MLP (CPU or GPU), compute train/val MSE, save all plottable arrays into ./working/experiment_data.npy, and save 1-2 matplotlib figures into ./working. The main success signal is that validation MSE decreases versus the initial value and remains finite (no NaNs).
Experiments: Generate x in [-3.14, 3.14] and y = sin(x) + Gaussian noise, split into train/val with a fixed seed.
Train a small MLP regressor in PyTorch for a small number of epochs (keep runtime short), track train/val MSE each epoch.
Save experiment_data.npy under ./working with a clear structure containing losses and metrics (train/val MSE).
Create and save plots: loss curve and predicted-vs-true scatter/curve for the validation set.
Risk Factors and Limitations: This is not a research contribution; it is only for smoke testing the pipeline.
If GPU is used, numerical nondeterminism may cause small metric differences across runs.
